Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-day history of gradually worsening lower back pain, localized predominantly to the left side. She initially attributed it to muscle strain after some light gardening. The pain is described as a deep, constant ache, now rated 6/10, and has started to radiate mildly to her left groin and anterior thigh over the past 24 hours. She also reports feeling unusually fatigued and a bit 'unsteady on her feet' since yesterday. She has taken paracetamol with minimal relief.
Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Atrial fibrillation (on warfarin), Hypertension, Osteoarthritis of knees and hips. No history of kidney stones, peptic ulcer disease, or major abdominal surgery. No known bleeding disorders. Last colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired schoolteacher. Lives alone in a bungalow. Non-smoker. Drinks one glass of wine with dinner 2-3 times a week. Ambulates independently, usually active with gardening.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Warfarin (dose recently adjusted by clinic, last INR 2 weeks ago was 2.8, target 2.0-3.0), Ramipril 5mg OD, Amlodipine 5mg OD, Paracetamol 1g PRN for osteoarthritis.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, night sweats. Denies frank weakness in legs but reports the 'unsteadiness'. Denies new cough or dyspnea. Denies chest pain or palpitations (aware of her AF). Denies dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, or visible hematuria. Bowel habit unchanged recently, no melena or hematochezia. Appetite slightly reduced over the past day. No significant recent weight loss. No skin rashes or new joint pains. No history of recent falls or significant trauma, other than usual gardening activity.

Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System: Intact to light touch and pinprick in all dermatomes, though patient reports vague altered sensation over anterior left thigh. Proprioception intact.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes: Biceps, triceps, brachioradialis 2+ and symmetrical. Patellar reflexes 2+ bilaterally. Achilles reflexes 2+ bilaterally. Plantars downgoing.
Neurological_Examination.Coordination_and_Gait: Finger-nose and heel-shin tests normal. Gait is cautious and slow due to pain, slightly antalgic favoring the left. Romberg test negative.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Irregularly irregular rhythm. S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Peripheral pulses palpable and symmetrical. No peripheral edema.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes or crackles. Symmetric chest expansion.

Blood_Tests.Group_and_Save: O positive, antibodies negative. Sample sent for crossmatch.

ECG.Findings: Atrial fibrillation, ventricular rate 95-105 bpm. No acute ST-T wave changes suggestive of ischemia. QTc normal.

Lumbar_Spine_Xray.Findings: Age-appropriate degenerative changes with mild lumbar spondylosis. No acute fracture, subluxation, or lytic/blastic lesions identified. Intervertebral disc spaces appear maintained.

Ultrasound_Abdomen_Renal_Pelvis.Findings: Technically limited study due to overlying bowel gas, particularly in the retroperitoneum. Both kidneys are normal in size and echotexture, with no hydronephrosis or definite calculi. Spleen normal. A small amount of free fluid in the pelvis noted, non-specific. The psoas muscles were poorly visualized. A definitive source for pain was not identified.

CT_Abdomen_Pelvis_non_contrast.Findings: Large, high-attenuation collection consistent with hematoma is seen within the left retroperitoneal space, predominantly involving and expanding the left psoas muscle and extending inferiorly along the iliopsoas into the pelvis. The hematoma measures approximately 15cm craniocaudally x 8cm AP x 6cm transverse at its maximal dimensions. The left kidney is displaced anteriorly but appears intrinsically normal. No definite perinephric component. No evidence of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

CT_Abdomen_Pelvis_with_IV_contrast_arter.Findings: Confirms the large left retroperitoneal/psoas hematoma. No active extravasation of intravenous contrast identified on arterial or portal venous phases to suggest ongoing rapid hemorrhage. The left ureter is seen draped over the anterior aspect of the hematoma but is not significantly dilated. Other abdominal organs appear unremarkable. Small pelvic free fluid re-demonstrated.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Retroperitoneal haemorrhage (psoas hematoma) secondary to over-anticoagulation with Warfarin

Ultrasound_Abdomen_focused_bedside.Findings: Technically limited study due to overlying bowel gas and patient discomfort. The infrarenal abdominal aorta appears dilated, measuring approximately 6.2 cm in maximal anteroposterior diameter. Some hypoechoic free fluid is noted in the pelvis and Morrison's pouch. Kidneys appear grossly normal. No gallstones or biliary ductal dilatation. Definitive site of aortic pathology or source of free fluid not clearly visualized.

CT_Abdomen_Pelvis_with_IV_contrast.Findings: Large fusiform infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm identified, measuring 6.8 cm in maximum transverse diameter and 7.2 cm in anteroposterior diameter, extending to the aortic bifurcation. Clear evidence of acute rupture with a large, complex retroperitoneal hematoma, predominantly on the left side, extending into the left psoas muscle, left perinephric space, and inferiorly into the pelvis. Active extravasation of contrast medium is identified from the posterolateral aspect of the aneurysm sac on the left. Mild bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter are present, likely secondary to compression by the hematoma. The visualized portions of the liver, spleen, pancreas, and bowel loops are unremarkable. No evidence of pulmonary embolism on visualized lung bases.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient, a retired postal worker, presents with a 9-month history of intermittent lower back pain. He describes the pain as a deep ache, primarily in the lumbar region, which has gradually become more frequent. More recently, over the past 3-4 months, he has noticed an unusual sensation in his legs, particularly after walking for more than 10-15 minutes. He finds it difficult to describe, stating it's a 'heaviness' or 'tiredness' in both thighs and sometimes calves, rather than sharp pain. He mentions that if he stops and leans against a wall for a few minutes, or sits down, the leg sensation tends to ease, allowing him to continue. He initially thought this was just 'old age' or poor circulation, as he has a history of borderline high cholesterol. He denies any specific injury. The back pain itself is not significantly worse with coughing or sneezing. He has tried over-the-counter pain relievers with minimal and temporary benefit.

Secondary_Symptoms: Leg symptoms partially relieved by rest or changing posture (e.g. leaning)
Gradual onset of symptoms over months

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (well-controlled on Lisinopril 10mg OD). Dyslipidemia (managed with diet, borderline high LDL on last check 1 year ago). Osteoarthritis in right knee (diagnosed 5 years ago, uses OTC NSAIDs as needed). No history of diabetes mellitus, no previous back surgery or major spinal trauma. Denies history of cancer. Appendectomy age 25.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired postal worker (involved significant walking). Smokes 5 cigarettes per day (previously smoked 15/day for 30 years, quit for 10 years, restarted 2 years ago). Drinks 1-2 glasses of wine per week. Lives with his wife. Ambulates independently but finds longer walks increasingly challenging due to leg symptoms.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, or unexplained weight loss. No night sweats. Reports occasional mild constipation, attributes to diet and reduced activity. Denies urinary incontinence, urinary retention, or saddle anesthesia. Denies frank, sudden weakness in legs, but notes the 'tiredness' can make them feel less responsive or 'heavy'. No morning stiffness lasting more than 15-20 minutes, mainly in back and right knee. No skin changes on legs (e.g. discoloration, hair loss). Denies chest pain or palpitations. Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. No recent falls.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, cooperative male, appears stated age. Moves somewhat stiffly but without acute distress. Not using any walking aids today.

Back_Examination.Inspection: No gross deformities, scars, or skin changes. Mild loss of lumbar lordosis observed.
Back_Examination.Palpation: Mild tenderness to palpation over L4-L5 paraspinal muscles bilaterally. No palpable step-offs or significant muscle spasm.
Back_Examination.Range_of_Motion: Lumbar flexion moderately reduced (fingertips to mid-shin), reports some back discomfort at end range. Extension is more limited (by approximately 30-40%) and he reports an increase in his usual low back ache and a vague 'tightness' developing in his posterior thighs when asked to maintain extension for 10 seconds. Lateral flexion mildly reduced bilaterally, more to the left.
Back_Examination.Special_Tests: Straight Leg Raise (SLR) negative bilaterally at 90 degrees (no radicular pain). Femoral stretch test negative bilaterally. Schober's test indicates reduced lumbar flexion.

Neurological_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Motor: Power 5/5 in all major muscle groups (hip flexion, extension, abduction, adduction; knee flexion, extension; ankle dorsiflexion, plantarflexion, eversion, inversion; great toe extension) when tested in supine position. No overt muscle atrophy evident.
Neurological_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Sensation: Intact to light touch and pinprick in all dermatomes (L1-S2). Vibration sense subjectively slightly diminished at both great toes compared to ankles, symmetrically. Proprioception intact.
Neurological_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Reflexes: Patellar reflexes (L3, L4) 2+ bilaterally. Achilles reflexes (S1) 1+ bilaterally (slightly diminished but present and symmetrical). Plantar responses flexor bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Gait: Gait observed for a short distance in the room is steady with normal base width. No foot drop. Patient asked to walk for 5 minutes in hallway: after approximately 3-4 minutes, reports onset of bilateral thigh 'heaviness' and his pace slows. He is observed to lean forward slightly on a nearby handrail. When asked to walk on heels and toes, able to do so but reports increased leg fatigue and posterior thigh discomfort quickly, especially on toe walking.
Neurological_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Coordination: Heel-to-shin test normal bilaterally. Romberg test negative.

Vascular_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Pulses: Femoral pulses 2+ bilaterally. Popliteal pulses 1+ bilaterally (palpable but weaker). Dorsalis pedis 1+ bilaterally. Posterior tibial pulses 1+ bilaterally. Pulses feel somewhat weaker than expected for age but are present.
Vascular_Examination_Lower_Limbs.Skin: No significant hair loss on lower legs or feet. Skin warm to touch. No edema. No varicosities. Capillary refill <3 seconds in toes. No ulcerations or trophic changes.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Hip_Examination: Range of motion of hips: Flexion to 110 degrees bilaterally, internal rotation to 20 degrees bilaterally, external rotation to 40 degrees bilaterally. Mild discomfort in right hip at extreme internal rotation, consistent with known OA. No crepitus reproduced with leg symptoms.

X-ray_Lumbar_Spine_AP_Lateral_Flexion_Ex.Findings: Multilevel degenerative disc disease, most prominent at L4-L5 and L5-S1 with disc space narrowing and anterior osteophyte formation. Mild facet joint arthropathy noted at L3-L4, L4-L5. No acute fracture. No dynamic instability (spondylolisthesis) evident on flexion-extension views. Overall alignment maintained. Sacroiliac joints appear normal.

Ankle_Brachial_Index_ABI.Interpretation: Values are in the borderline range (0.91-0.99). Does not strongly suggest hemodynamically significant peripheral arterial disease as the primary cause of claudication, but mild PAD cannot be entirely excluded.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine_without_contrast.Findings: Significant multilevel degenerative changes. At L4-L5: Broad-based posterior disc bulge, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, and facet joint arthropathy contributing to moderate to severe central canal stenosis (AP diameter approximately 6mm) and bilateral moderate lateral recess stenosis, with contact and probable impingement on the traversing L5 nerve roots bilaterally. At L3-L4: Mild central canal stenosis due to disc bulge and facet arthropathy. At L5-S1: Mild disc bulge and mild bilateral foraminal narrowing, no significant central stenosis. No evidence of acute large disc herniation, tumor, or infection. Vertebral body heights maintained.

Electromyography_Nerve_Conduction_Studie.Rationale: MRI findings are quite explanatory for neurogenic claudication. EMG/NCS might be considered if symptoms are atypical, there's suspicion of coexisting peripheral neuropathy not explained by other tests, or for pre-surgical planning if conservative measures fail.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Claudication: neurogenic (due to lumbar spinal stenosis, predominantly at L4-L5)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 6-month history of insidious onset lower back pain. He describes it as a dull ache, primarily in the lumbar region, rated 4/10 at rest. The pain significantly worsens to 7/10 with activity, particularly walking. He states that after walking for about 10-15 minutes, or less if walking uphill, the ache intensifies in his lower back and also begins to radiate into both buttocks and occasionally the posterior thighs, feeling like a 'deep heaviness'. Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 9-month history of lower back pain, described as a persistent, deep ache. Back_Examination.Palpation: Mild tenderness elicited over bilateral sacroiliac joints and lower lumbar paraspinal muscles. No point tenderness over spinous processes.
Back_Examination.Range_of_Motion_Lumbar_Spine: Flexion slightly limited by pain at end-range. Extension, lateral bending, and rotation appear full, though causing some discomfort.
Back_Examination.Neurological_Examination_Lower_Limbs: Straight leg raise negative bilaterally. Motor power 5/5 in all major muscle groups. Sensation intact to light touch and pinprick throughout. Deep tendon reflexes (patellar, Achilles) 2+ and symmetric. Babinski sign negative bilaterally.

Abdominal_Examination.Auscultation: Normoactive bowel sounds in all four quadrants.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft. Mild deep tenderness elicited in the suprapubic area and left lower quadrant. No guarding, rebound tenderness, or palpable masses. Liver and spleen not palpable.

Pelvic_Examination.Speculum_Examination: Cervix appears nulliparous, pink, with no visible lesions or active discharge. Small amount of clear physiological vaginal discharge noted in the vault.
Pelvic_Examination.Bimanual_Examination: Uterus is anteverted, normal size, and mobile, though cervical motion elicits some discomfort. Ovaries not clearly delineated separately.

X_Ray_Lumbar_Spine.Findings: Mild degenerative changes noted at L4-L5 and L5-S1 vertebral bodies. Intervertebral disc spaces appear maintained. No acute fracture, subluxation, or spondylolisthesis identified. Sacroiliac joints appear radiographically normal.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine.Findings: Minor posterior disc bulge at L5-S1 without significant neural foraminal narrowing or evidence of nerve root impingement. Mild facet joint arthropathy at L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels. The spinal canal is patent. Conus medullaris terminates at L1 and appears normal. Sacroiliac joints demonstrate no evidence of active sacroiliitis. No paravertebral collections or masses.

Pelvic_Ultrasound_Transvaginal.Findings: Anteverted uterus, normal size (7cm x 4cm x 3.5cm) and myometrial echotexture. Endometrial thickness 8mm, appropriate for mid-cycle. Right ovary measures 3.0 x 2.0 cm, normal morphology with several small follicles. Left ovary measures 3.5 x 2.5 cm and contains a 2.5 cm complex cyst with diffuse low-level internal echoes, suspicious for either a hemorrhagic cyst or a small endometrioma; follow-up imaging is suggested. No adnexal masses otherwise. No free fluid in the cul-de-sac. Tenderness was elicited with transvaginal probe pressure in the left adnexal region and posterior fornix. Limited detailed visualization of uterosacral ligaments due to overlying bowel gas.

MRI_Pelvis_with_Endometriosis_Protocol.Findings: Anteverted uterus, normal zonal anatomy. The previously identified 2.5 cm left ovarian cyst demonstrates T1 hyperintensity and T2 shading, consistent with a small endometrioma. Several punctate foci of T1 hyperintensity are noted along the surface of both uterosacral ligaments, more prominent on the left, suggestive of superficial endometriotic implants. Mild thickening and irregularity of the left uterosacral ligament. No definite evidence of deep infiltrating endometriosis involving the bowel, bladder, or rectovaginal septum. Small physiological volume of free fluid in the pelvis. Right ovary normal.

Diagnostic_Laparoscopy_and_Biopsy.Procedure_Summary: Diagnostic laparoscopy performed due to persistent pain, MRI findings, and elevated CA-125.
Diagnostic_Laparoscopy_and_Biopsy.Findings: Multiple characteristic pigmented (blue-black, reddish, and white opacified) lesions noted on the pelvic peritoneum, particularly involving the posterior cul-de-sac, both uterosacral ligaments (more extensive on the left), and bilateral ovarian fossae. The 2.5cm endometrioma on the left ovary was confirmed and drained, showing typical chocolate-like fluid. Filmy adhesions were noted between the posterior aspect of the uterus and the rectum, and tethering the left ovary to the pelvic sidewall. Fallopian tubes appeared patent with fimbrial spill of dye. Biopsies were taken from several peritoneal lesions and the wall of the ovarian cyst.
Diagnostic_Laparoscopy_and_Biopsy.Histopathology_Results: Biopsies from peritoneal lesions and left ovarian cyst wall confirm the presence of endometrial glands and stroma, consistent with endometriosis. No evidence of malignancy.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine_with_and_without_Gadoli.Findings: Abnormal signal intensity (T1 hypointense, T2 hyperintense, and marked contrast enhancement) is demonstrated within the L3 and L4 vertebral bodies and the intervening L3-L4 intervertebral disc. These findings are consistent with active discitis and vertebral osteomyelitis. There is associated prevertebral and bilateral paravertebral soft tissue inflammation and enhancement. A small, elongated fluid collection/phlegmon is noted in the ventral epidural space at the L3-L4 level, causing mild indentation of the anterior apect of the thecal sac but no significant spinal canal stenosis or neural foraminal narrowing. No cord signal abnormality.

CT_Guided_Biopsy_L3_L4_disc_space_and_L4.Histopathology: Core biopsy specimens from the L3-L4 intervertebral disc and L4 vertebral body show fragments of fibrocartilage and bone with an extensive acute and chronic inflammatory infiltrate, including neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Necrotic debris present. No evidence of malignancy.
CT_Guided_Biopsy_L3_L4_disc_space_and_L4.Microbiology_Culture: Growth of Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) from tissue culture. Sensitivities consistent with blood culture isolate.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Vertebral osteomyelitis (L3-L4) with associated discitis and ventral epidural phlegmon, secondary to Staphylococcus aureus.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine_with_and_without_Gadoli.Findings: There is an elongated fluid collection within the ventral epidural space extending from L3 to S1, measuring approximately 6 cm in craniocaudal dimension and up to 1.2 cm in AP dimension. This collection is T1 hypointense, T2 hyperintense, and demonstrates peripheral rim enhancement following gadolinium administration. There is associated mass effect on the thecal sac and cauda equina nerve roots, particularly on the left at L4-S1 levels. The adjacent L4 and L5 vertebral bodies and intervening L4/L5 disc show abnormal signal with T2 hyperintensity and enhancement, consistent with early osteomyelitis/discitis. Mild diffuse bulging of the L4/5 disc without frank herniation. The conus medullaris terminates at L1 and appears normal. No definite subdural component clearly identified, but cannot be entirely excluded given the extent of inflammation.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Lumbar Epidural Abscess with associated L4/L5 Spondylodiscitis

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 6-week history of progressively worsening lower back pain. The pain began insidiously, initially described as a dull ache in the lumbosacral region, which he attributed to muscle strain after gardening. Over the past 2-3 weeks, the pain has become more constant, severe (rated 7-8/10), and now significantly disturbs his sleep. It is characterized as a deep, boring pain, primarily localized to the lower lumbar area, sometimes with a vague, non-dermatomal radiation to the posterior aspect of both thighs, not extending below the knees. He reports feeling generally unwell and fatigued for approximately one month, accompanied by a reduced appetite and an unintentional weight loss of 3 kg over this period. He recalls having a lower molar extraction about 2 months prior, which he states healed without any immediate complications. He denies any specific acute trauma or injury to his back.

Neurological_Examination.Motor_System_Lower_Limbs: Power 5/5 in hip flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension, ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion bilaterally. No overt muscle atrophy.
Neurological_Examination.Sensory_System_Lower_Limbs: Sensation to light touch and pinprick generally intact throughout lower limbs. Patient reports a subjective, poorly localized area of slightly diminished sensation over the anterolateral aspect of the left thigh, but this is inconsistent on repeat testing and not clearly dermatomal. Vibration and proprioception intact bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Reflexes_Lower_Limbs: Patellar reflexes ++ and symmetrical. Achilles reflexes ++ and symmetrical. Plantar responses flexor bilaterally.
Neurological_Examination.Coordination_and_Gait: Gait is antalgic, slow, and guarded with a wide base. Unable to perform heel walk or toe walk due to severe back pain. Finger-nose and heel-shin tests performed adequately when supine.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present and normal. No palpable masses or organomegaly. No abdominal bruits. No costovertebral angle tenderness.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Peripheral pulses palpable and symmetrical.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Respiratory_Examination: Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. No added sounds. Symmetric chest expansion.

Blood_Tests.Blood_Cultures: One of two sets positive for Staphylococcus aureus (Methicillin-Sensitive Staphylococcus Aureus - MSSA). Second set no growth.

X_Ray_Lumbar_Spine.Findings: Anteroposterior and lateral views show subtle narrowing of the L4-L5 disc space. Mild degenerative endplate sclerosis is noted at L4 and L5. No acute fracture, dislocation, or obvious destructive bony lesion identified. Overall alignment is maintained. Findings are non-specific and could represent chronic degenerative changes.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine_with_and_without_contra.Findings: There is abnormal T1 hypointense and T2/STIR hyperintense signal within the L4-L5 intervertebral disc and the adjacent vertebral body endplates of L4 and L5. Following administration of gadolinium contrast, there is avid enhancement of the L4-L5 disc, the involved endplates, and surrounding prevertebral and bilateral paravertebral soft tissues. Small, enhancing fluid collections are noted within the psoas muscles bilaterally at the L4-L5 level, consistent with inflammation/myositis. Mild ventral epidural enhancement is present at L4-L5 without significant spinal canal stenosis or neural compression. The remaining lumbar discs and vertebral bodies appear unremarkable. Findings are highly suggestive of L4-L5 discitis and osteomyelitis with associated psoas muscle involvement.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Infection: Septic discitis (L4-L5) with associated osteomyelitis and psoas muscle inflammation, secondary to Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia.

XRay_Lumbar_Spine_AP_and_Lateral.Findings: Moderate degenerative spondylosis with disc space narrowing most prominent at L4-L5 and L5-S1, and associated facet joint arthropathy. The L4 vertebral body appears subtly expanded with evidence of cortical thickening and a coarsened, somewhat sclerotic trabecular pattern. Similar, less distinct changes are questioned in the S1 segment. No acute fracture, spondylolisthesis, or overt destructive lesion identified. These findings, particularly at L4, are somewhat atypical for uncomplicated degenerative disease and raise the possibility of an underlying metabolic bone condition such as Paget disease.

Bone_Scan_Whole_Body_Technetium_99m_MDP.Findings: Multiple areas of intensely increased radiotracer uptake are demonstrated in the axial and appendicular skeleton. Specifically, marked uptake is seen involving the L4 vertebral body, the entirety of the sacrum, and the right hemipelvis (ilium, ischium, and pubis). Less intense, heterogeneous uptake is noted in the left proximal femur. Mild degenerative uptake is present in the knees and small joints of the hands. The pattern and intensity of uptake in the lumbar spine, sacrum, and pelvis are highly characteristic of active Paget disease of bone. No focal lesions suspicious for widespread metastatic disease.

STIR sequences demonstrate small foci of increased signal (bone marrow edema) at the anterior corners of the T12 and L1 vertebral bodies, consistent with Romanus lesions (early enthesitis). Mild facet joint arthropathy at L4-L5. No evidence of discitis, osteomyelitis, or malignant infiltration.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient presents with a 6-month history of insidious onset lower back pain, primarily in the buttock region, sometimes alternating sides. He describes it as a deep ache and stiffness, particularly severe in the morning upon waking, lasting for approximately 60-90 minutes, and gradually improving with movement and light exercise throughout the day. Over the past 2-3 months, he has also experienced intermittent, mild lower abdominal cramping and a change in bowel habits, with stools being looser than usual (Bristol type 5-6), occurring 2-3 times per day on some days, without visible blood, mucus, or nocturnal diarrhea. He hasn't significantly altered his diet. He reports feeling more fatigued than usual over the last few months, impacting his concentration at work. Denies any specific injury or trauma preceding the back pain.

X_ray_Lumbar_Spine_and_Pelvis.Findings: Anteroposterior and lateral views of the lumbar spine show mild straightening of the normal lumbar lordosis. Vertebral body heights and disc spaces are maintained. No acute fractures or spondylolisthesis. Sacroiliac joints appear hazy bilaterally with some subtle sclerosis noted, particularly on the iliac side. No definitive erosions or ankylosis identified. No significant degenerative changes.

MRI_Sacroiliac_Joints_with_and_without_c.Findings: T2-weighted and STIR sequences demonstrate significant bone marrow edema consistent with active sacroiliitis bilaterally, more prominent on the iliac aspect of the joints. Mild synovitis and capsulitis also noted. No definite chronic structural changes such as erosions, sclerosis, or ankylosis are clearly visible. Abdominal_Ultrasound.Findings: Performed due to intermittent abdominal symptoms and elevated inflammatory markers. Liver, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, and kidneys appear sonographically normal. No free fluid or obvious mass. Limited views of the bowel, but a short segment of the terminal ileum appeared to have mildly thickened walls (approx 4mm). Suggest correlation with other findings.

Stool_Studies.Stool_Culture_Ova_and_Parasites: Negative for enteric pathogens, ova, and parasites.

Colonoscopy_with_ileoscopy_and_biopsies.Findings: Procedure performed to the terminal ileum. Patchy mild erythema and scattered small aphthous ulcers (2-4mm) noted in the terminal ileum (last 10cm) and in the cecum and ascending colon. The transverse, descending, sigmoid colon and rectum appeared grossly normal. Multiple biopsies taken from all segments, including areas of abnormality and normal-appearing mucosa.

Histopathology_Colon_Biopsies.Findings: Terminal ileum and right colon biopsies show features of chronic inflammation, including crypt architectural distortion, basal plasmacytosis, and focal collections of neutrophils within crypt epithelium (cryptitis). Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes noted. No granulomas identified. No features of dysplasia or malignancy. Findings are consistent with mild inflammatory bowel disease, features could be seen in early Crohn's disease or an unclassified inflammatory bowel disorder.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Axial Spondyloarthritis (likely Ankylosing Spondylitis given SI joint involvement and HLA-B27 positivity) with associated mild Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Enteropathic Arthritis)

Xray_Lumbar_Spine_AP_Lateral_Flexion_Ext.Findings: Anterolisthesis of L5 on S1 is evident, measuring approximately 7mm on the neutral lateral view, consistent with Meyerding Grade I. Bilateral pars interarticularis defects (spondylolysis) are suspected at L5. Mild degenerative disc disease is noted at L4-L5 and L5-S1, with minimal osteophyte formation. Vertebral body heights and alignment otherwise maintained. No acute fracture or destructive osseous lesion identified. Flexion-extension views demonstrate minimal change in the degree of anterolisthesis (<3mm translation), suggesting no gross dynamic instability.

MRI_Lumbar_Spine_without_contrast.Findings: Confirms Grade I anterolisthesis of L5 on S1 (measured at 7mm) secondary to bilateral L5 pars interarticularis defects. This results in mild to moderate bilateral L5-S1 neural foraminal stenosis, which appears slightly more pronounced on the right side, with contact and possible mild irritation of the exiting right L5 nerve root within the foramen. No significant central canal stenosis. Mild disc desiccation and minimal loss of disc height at L5-S1. Other lumbar levels are unremarkable. The conus medullaris terminates normally at L1 and appears unremarkable. No evidence of spinal tumor, infection, or acute compressive disc herniation.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Grade I Isthmic Spondylolisthesis at L5-S1 with associated bilateral L5 pars interarticularis defects, resulting in mild right L5 neural foraminal stenosis and symptoms suggestive of mild right L5 nerve root irritation.

He denies any specific acute injury. He finds some temporary, partial relief lying supine with pillows under his knees. Over-the-counter ibuprofen provides only minimal relief. He reports feeling more fatigued than usual, which he attributes to disturbed sleep due to the pain. He also mentions some intermittent, mild lower abdominal bloating and a feeling of increased urinary urgency over the past week, which he is unsure if related; he denies dysuria, hematuria, or changes in bowel habit other than mild constipation he attributes to reduced activity.
